climbs.name: Wrist Rocket
climbs.fa: EFR, Jim Scott, Erik Murdock, Doug Cormick

content.description: This route has a devious crux.  Once deciphered it is not hard but getting the sequence dialed took a number of tries.     If you want helpful but by no means give away beta read on.  If you want no beta stop reading now.  Where the wall gets steep move right past short steep crack to big round knob on a big ledge.
content.location: This route is on the back, up road side of the Green Slabs.  It starts on a slightly fuzzy slab and angles up and left.

content.description: Fun with taped hands or 5.10 rubber crack glove a bit harsh otherwise.  It is a good crack and it's worth doing as the pro is good.
content.protection: Standard Mt. Lemmon Rack, go light on the stoppers.
content.location: North side of Green Slabs.  Climb crack in orange streak about 20 left of the arete.  Move right to avoid climbing over relatively solid natural bridge.  Lower from chains.

climbs.name: Pettycoat Junction
climbs.fa: EFR, JSt, Wing Ng, Scott Conners, '06

content.description: Fun climbing at the start leads you around the left side of the bulgy roof to big ledge.  From here you climb the striking left facing dihedral.  The exit of this is very fun and may be the crux.  Above this you stay left on the easier rock until you can head back right on to the upper face.
content.location: This climb starts on the left side of a steep orange face that is capped by a bulgy roof.  The hangers are rust colored.

climbs.name: Little Jack Corner
climbs.fa: EFR, JSt, Wing Ng, Scott Conners,'06

content.description: Not pretty to look at but fun to climb.  The crack leads to a fun corner with a crack in it.
content.protection: Standard rack.  The #3 cam makes the crack above the big ledge safe but you have to make a protected move to get it.
content.location: Start either in the ugly gully or avoid most of it by moving up hill 15 feet or so then follow staircase up and right.  At large ledge climb the right of two cracks.

climbs.name: Hooterville
climbs.fa: JSt, EFR, Wing Ng, Scott Conners,'06

content.description: The crux is turning the roof at the top of the steep orange face.  You can add a letter grade or two if you are shorter than 5 feet 4.  At the bolt below the roof of the upper dihedral it is easiest to go straight over roof.  This is where you will find the jugs.  Going left is 5.10 or so.
content.protection: Mostly bolts.  You will want to take a #3 Camalot to get you to the bolt above the ledge.  A wired nut finger sized or bigger can go in above the bolt.  Then a couple of finger sized nuts will get you to the final bolt 20 feet higher.
content.location: This route climbs the right side of the steep orange face that is capped by a roof band.  You are on the right route if a staircase of ledges lead up and right to a crack gully system.  This stair case is the start of Little Jack Corner.

content.description: Climb slab up to left angling dihedral then over bulge.  The crux is near the top and there are two ways to do it, straight over bolt or just left of the bolt.  Good rock, and interesting climbing only five minutes from the road.
content.location: Walk up the road from the Green Slabs parking area at MP 9.9.  Drop down into the stream bed.  Walk upstream 100 feet then head to the big downed tree.  Contour back right to the base of the wall.

climbs.name: Green Eggs And Cams
climbs.fa: Jim Scott, Doug Cormick, Erik Murdock, EFR

content.description: A nice crack with good pro.  The first 20 feet is steep, while the rest is still fun but not so steep. It's a little scary if you move left rather than staying in the shallow dihedral about ten feet up.  Step right at the little rock bridge.
content.protection: Standard rack with doubles on the blue and green Camalots.
content.location: First crack left of the arete.  It looks harder than Time Warp but isn't.

content.description: The crux is hard laybacks down low.  At the top is a big alcove you have to power your way out of.
content.location: On the up road side of Green Slabs.  Head up the stream bed about 100 feet then head right for a large downed tree.  Hike up next to it half way then contour back  to the wall.  This route starts left of Greenhorn and just right of a broken up gully.

content.description:
Green Acres (North Face), which is located on the north face of the Green Slabs Area is a small, lush crag that never sees sun.  The routes force peculiar movement over undulating, twisted features.  The fractured rock creates a feeling of unease but somehow manages to hold together.  Green Acres (North Face) is a bizarre, unique, slightly unnerving crag with both sport and trad lines. 

  Due to the nature of the rock a helmet is recommended for the belayer.
